pr_title: Issue 5111: Consumption based retention policy implementation

timeline.bodyText: Using updateStream() API when a user tries to switch the Retention Policy for an existing Stream( Stream created prior to 0.9) from non-CBR to CBR, we need to invoke createSubscribersRecordIfAbsent to make sure the SubscribersSet Record is created in the Stream metadata table. Without this add/createSubscriber would fail for existing Streams.

timeline.bodyText:
We need to add tests to cover the following corner cases:

CBR Retention Policy does not specify any max/min limit (so they are at their default values)
Stream does not have any subscribers (# of subscribers = 0 and/or no subscriber has a valid StreamCut... there have been addSubscriber() calls but no updateSubscriberStreamCut() calls so far)
Stream has few subscribers with empty StreamCuts (StreamCuts have not been updated from client so far)
timeline.author: pbelgundi

replies.bodyText:
is handled via the CBR policy constructor itself. if nothing is specified the max is long.max and min is defaulted to 0.


and 3.
if one or more subscribers have not updated their streamcut then they are effectively at the mercy of "min".
should we wait for all subscribers to have reported at least one streamcut? if that is preferred i will make the change.
replies.author: shiveshr

replies.bodyText:
I understand that default max==LONG_MAX and default min==0, I'm suggesting having a test case that invokes CBR Stream truncation without these values being explicitly set, just to cover the scenario where customers may not set these limits. I know it should work, but having a test case to validate would be good.


if one or more subscribers have not updated their streamcut then they are effectively at the mercy of "min".
Yes this is by design.
replies.author: pbelgundi

replies.bodyText:
should we wait for all subscribers to have reported at least one streamcut? if that is preferred i will make the change.

No we should not wait for any subscriber to update their Stream cut. Truncation can happen with 0 subscribers/valid-streamcuts ....its just that it will happen at the max value instead of the lowerBound.
We just need to make sure these corner cases are tested

timeline.bodyText: In the case where a Stream has only a single Subscriber, there is no need to compute a "lower bound" and we could short circuit this computation and directly return the Stream-Cut  corresponding to that Subscriber.
timeline.author: pbelgundi

replies.bodyText: It may be good to add a test case covering this scenario.
replies.author: pbelgundi

replies.bodyText: created an issue to tackle it later. #5349
replies.author: shiveshr

replies.bodyText: It should be a small change. I think we should do it as part of this PR itself.
replies.author: pbelgundi

replies.bodyText:
the reason is "lowerbound" is Map<Long, Long> while subscriber's streamcut is Map<StreamSegmentRecord, Long> so there is one pass needed to convert even the single subscriber to Map<Long, Long>.
so the suggested optimization will not yield anything.
what we can do instead is optimize the code a bit to not have to deal with these different types of maps but unify it. hence i will address this and other optimization in a separate PR.

unknown, as explained, is not a valid use case. it is a protobuf enum evolution safety measure to allow for new values to be mapped to unknown.
if we want NONE, that should be added separately. However, i think a limit with null on min or max or both is sufficient to provide that and we may not need a separate enum type NONE
